description: Parenthesized one way gives the powers of 2: (1), (2), (1+3), ..., another way the powers of 3: (1), (2+1), (3+6), ....
comments: Powers of 2 need 1 term or 2 terms parenthesized, whereas powers of 3 need 2 or 3 terms parenthesized, when 3 then the middle term is a power of 2. See A227928. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Oct 09 2013
references: N. J. A. Sloane and Simon Plouffe, The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences, Academic Press, 1995 (includes this sequence).
links: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1000
prog: (Haskell)a006895 n = a006895_list !! na006895_list = 1 : f 0 0 (tail a000079_list) (tail a000244_list) where   f x y us'@(u:us) vs'@(v:vs)     | x > 0     = (u - x) : f 0 (u - x + y) us vs'     | y > v - u = (v - y) : f (v + x - y) 0 us' vs     | otherwise =       u : f 0 (u + y) us vs'-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Oct 09 2013
author: _N. J. A. Sloane_, K. S. Brown [ kevin2003(AT)delphi.com ]
